subject: Re: JUnit 4 restructuring
msgSnippet: Thank you very much for your reply, I d be very interested in what the other developers on this mailing list think about @Before and @BeforeTestMethod, because
messageBody:
Thank you very much for your reply,
I'd be very interested in what the other developers on this mailing list
think about @Before and @BeforeTestMethod, because the people you have asked
might think that @BeforeTestMethod reads better if given the option. So to
everybody who's reading this: please comment on this question.

What do you think about Joe Walnes' Flexible JUnit
assertions<http://64.233.161.104/search?q=cache:k4i4bq5MGYMJ:joe.truemesh.com/blog/000511.html+>(this
is a link to Google's cache because his site seems to be down at the
moment) and my aproach<http://saloon.javaranch.com/cgi-bin/ubb/ultimatebb.cgi?ubb=get_topic&f=68&t=000944>
?

On 10/22/05, Kent Beck <kentb@...> wrote:
>
> Thank you for the feedback. My own experience and that of most of the
> people
> who have responded is that @Before and @After read well. I suppose it
> depends a little on how many annotations are present. I don't use any
> other
> annotations in my code, but I can see that @BeforeTestMethod might stand
> out
> better if there were many other annotations. [...]
>


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
